Made from 18 gauge 925 sterling silver.
Its small and has grown since then, but it worked well for me.
Hand cut TINY sakura blossoms.
These made my hands and eyes hurt a little.
I used a glue stick to attach the template to the copper, this allows the template to be easily removed with water.
Hand cut TINY sakura blossoms.
These made my hands and eyes hurt a little.
All cut out and cleaned up.
Argentium silver wires with a ball melted on the end
The blossoms have their center hole drilled and radiused.
I added some tiny divots to make the center of the blossoms look more like cherry blossoms.
All soldered together, ready for an acid bath to clean them up.
A delicate bouquet of sakura blossoms.
Still a little flat though.
I added some curve to the petals, more like the real thing.
The wires are trimmed to the proper earring post length.
All ready for some polish.
I fabricated a branch from sterling silver and attached a few of the blossoms to create a matching pendant.
All soldered together and fresh out of the acid bath, ready for polish.
The original design sketch and a few calculations for the solar system pendant.
The backing is soldered and ready to be cut out and cleaned up.
I added a few rings, and cut out the crescent moon.
It doesn't always go smoothly, sometimes you need to fail until you figure it out.
Using the laser cutter transfer paper method I prepared the background for acid etching.
All etched and ready to be cut out.
Because of the toner not always sticking, I had to etch about half a dozen of these to get a clean one.
All cut out and shiny
I drilled the holes for the sun and planets, and started with the sun.
Using my pulse arc welder I bonded the sun and planets to the background from the back.
I couldn't use normal solder methods because the back plate needed to be kept clean and shiny.
All attached and ready for some minor cleanup.
A test fit to get things right on the background piece before attaching it to the pendant.
With everything cleaned up and ready to be attached I did a bit of oxidation with liver of sulfur to add depth and texture.
The original concept sketch for the broken heart pendant.
Traced out and ready for the saw.
All cut out and ready for texture.
Beat up and stitched back together.
Adding a bit of curvature to the hearts.
Made from a beautiful piece of walnut
I taped the top and bottom together to ensure that they are exactly the same length when cut to length.
Using a forstner I made three matching compartments in the top and bottom.
The ring holder posts are made from pieces of walnut dowel.
A bit of test fitting with the rings.
I routed the edges of the box and added the hinges.
Final test fit to ensure that the box is good to go.
I added neodymium magnets to the box to hold it closed.
A coat of polyurethane to finish things up.
Felt protectors for the top and bottom surfaces.
Fabrication done.
I added felt to the bottom to cover the screw holes and protect any surfaces this is set on.
The final product with the rings.
It all started with a flat piece of sterling silver.
I added a hammered texture for looks.
Bent into a tube and soldered.
This will be the inner ring.
I bent and hammered a copper and a jeweler's bronze spinner.
Everything soldered up and fresh out of the acid bath.
Time to add the tubes for the gemstones.
Opposing tubes soldered up.
A test fit to ensure the ring is good to go.
Tubes shortened for the gemstones.
Gemstones set, this is the ruby side
Gemstones set, this is the amethyst side
Sketched out and ready to cut.
Cut out and fitted together.
Soldering on the outer bezel.
Bezels/Bails soldered.
Small bezels soldered in place.
Bezels trimmed and ready for cabochons.
Setting the moonstone cabochon.
One side polished, the other blackened.
Tiny copper hearts, coated with enameled glass.
Ready for the dangle chain and earwire.
Tiny copper hearts, coated with enameled glass.
Ready for the dangle chain and earwire.
Sterling silver cat and jeweler's bronze moon cut out and textured.
Test fit of the components.
All soldered together and ready for polish.
.999 Pure silver rings cut to size.
Rings for the ears trimmed and fitted to the head.
Using solder paste to ensure that the solder joints are nickel free
Soldered together and ready for the bail ring.
All done, ready for the final polish.
All the pieces cut, soldered and cleaned up.
Setting the tiny 2mm white sapphire stars.
Polishing time.
A dirty job, but this is where you really start to see the beauty of the piece.
Paper templates are attached with glue stick, this allows them to be easily removed with water, yet hold during sawing.
All cut out, rings soldered and ready for assembly.
A test fit to ensure the pendant is good to go for soldering.
I added a small triangular bail to the pendant.
Soldered together and ready for the final polish.
All the parts cut out and fitted together.
Tiny Temple.
This really hurt my fingers
Test fit of the components before soldering.
Main piece soldered together and ready to be attached to the bar.
Soldered together and ready for the final polish.
Textured and cut out.
Soldered on a tiny tube for a tiny stone.
Stone set, shiny and polished.
Textured, polished and connected together.
Polishing time.
Polishing time.
Trying out the new ring holder.
This is where the dimpled ring started
Tiny and shiny
Soldering these together takes a lot of patience.
